item.title: Use the Uchigatana in Your New Elden Ring Build in 2025
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/use-the-uchigatana-in-your-new-elden-ring-build-in-2025/

If your Elden Ring build revolves around the Samurai class and move set, chances are you want to track down and equip a second Uchigatana. Even if you’re not playing Samura, knowing where to find the Uchigatana in Elden Ring proves worthwhile, as it is a durable, quick weapon that scales with Strength and Dexterity.

Where is the Uchigatana in Elden Ring?

You can find the Uchigatana one of two ways, either as starting equipment for the Samurai class, as previously mentioned, or out in the world via a dungeon.

For the latter, you’ll find the Uchigatana in Deathtouched Catacombs, in Stormhill, Limgrave, where you’ll have to defeat a few skeletons and activate a lever to unlock the door leading into the hall.

Within the catacombs, fight through the undead until you discover a dead body handing over the edge of the floor. It’s here that you’ll find the Uchigatana.

How Good is the Uchigatana?

The Uchigatana in Elden Ring is one of the best early-game weapons, as it is viable for both Piercing and Slash Damage. Furthermore, its Weapon Skill, Unsheathe, can help you down most bosses with relative ease early on.

Thankfully, you can upgrade the Uchigatana using Smithing Stones, which makes it stronger overall. Over time, the blade will cause bleed buildup, which is ever-useful when dealing with bosses with an increased health pool.

And yes, you can infuse the Uchigatana with Ashes of War. These include the likes of Sword Dance, Vacuum Slice, Bloodhound’s Step, Raptor of the Mists, Lighting Slash, Flame of the Redmanes, Carian Grandeur, Bloody Slash, and Seppuku, among countless others.

Did you find the Uchigatana in Elden Ring? If so, does it play a significant role in your build? Let us know in the comments below, or visit the community forum to find players still enjoying Elden Ring!

item.title: Legless in London Brings Accessible Victorian Ambition
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/tabletop/news/legless-in-london-brings-accessible-victorian-ambition

A new board game is bringing more visibility to the disabled community. Focus Games has partnered with an accomplished humanities professor to produce Legless in London, a board game about playing as an amputee in Victorian London.

The Legless in London Announcement

According to the game's official page, Legless in London is a nuanced board game about disability.

It is a game where players face challenges, opportunities, and choices at every turn. They will navigate the workplace, the marriage market, property ownership, medicine, and the prosthesis market while aiming to achieve their character's personal goals.

The playable characters in Legless in London are all inspired by Victorian amputees and fictional characters from 19th-century literature. Everyone from beloved poet William Ernest Henley to Moby Dick's Captain Ahab are represented here.

In addition to being designed for fun, Legless in London encourages players to think about the various barriers that disabled people face in real life and the different hurdles they confront. Furthermore, the designers hope players will reflect on how disabled people are represented in fiction and popular culture.

Legless in London was designed in collaboration with Focus Games and Dr. Ryan Sweet, a Senior Lecturer in Humanities at Swansea University, alongside a focus group of members of the disabled community.

Disability and disability history are underrepresented in culture—and especially in tabletop gaming. Many mainstream tabletop games also present accessibility problems for disabled players (for example, wordy and/or complex rules, which can be troublesome for neurodivergent users). Legless in London addresses both representational and accessibility concerns as it provides a balanced, researched-informed, positive, and fun portrayal of disability in an inclusive format.

That consideration for disability also extends to the game's design. It will launch with a smartphone app, providing a digital alternative to the game's physical components including dice rolls, event cards, health tracker, and in-game money.

As for the physical components, the game will ship with large accessible font text, screen reader-friendly resources, easy-read rules, and more.

Legless in London will launch in February 2025.

item.title: Steam's Surprise End-Of-Year Hit Is A Psychological Horror Game About An Anime Girlfriend
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/miside-steam-reviews-mita-markiplier-anime-horror-1851730367

Steam’s latest mini-sensation has arrived and it’s called MiSide. The meta thriller in the vein of Doki Doki Literature Club has already racked up one of the highest ratings on Valve’s storefront just a couple weeks after its completely under-the-radar launch, thanks in part to streams by Mark “Markiplier” Fischbach and others.

Suggested Reading

The Top 10 Most-Played Games On Steam Deck: October 2023 Edition

  • Off
  • English

Suggested Reading

If you’re just starting to come back online after the holiday break, you might be surprised to learn that 2024 was hiding one last Steam hit up its digital sleeve. MiSide is an anime horror game about a programmer who finds himself magically transported into the world of a cute, minigame-filled mobile sim that’s home to his virtual love interest, Mita. The premise is a mashup of visual novel and cozy walking sim elements that eventually goes to some much weirder places and begins breaking the fourth wall in the process.

Markiplier streamed the game a couple of days after it came out and, weeks later, the VOD has accumulated over 3 million views. Special edd, xQc, and others have since reacted to the game as well. YouTube shorts and TikTok are also flooded with MiSide reaction videos and Mita fan cams. As a result, the game has over 43,000 reviews on Steam with a positive rating just a fraction higher than Balatro’s, making it one of the highest-ranked games on Valve’s storefront, at least for now.

MiSide’s success didn’t completely come out of nowhere. A very polished demo was released on itch.io over a year ago and quickly acquired fans. At this point, the comments page is filled with people sharing YouTube videos of their own playthroughs of the unsettling, creepypasta-infused, twist-filled story. In some ways it’s perfect catnip for the user-powered Steam algorithm: psychological horror + anime waifu + social media virality lottery = Steam’s first early winter breakout.

“Before the game’s release, we never expected MiSide to be so popular,” the game’s developers wrote on Steam last week alongside an update adding a photo mode and other tweaks. “We are very grateful to every player who supports us! In addition to continuing to polish the game and produce the planned content, we will also carefully consider future plans, which will cover all aspects of the game, both inside and outside the game. We will share new plans with everyone as soon as they are available!”

item.title: Wccftech’s Best Platformers of 2024 – Hop, Skip, Jump!
item.content:encoded:
https://wccftech.com/wccftechs-best-platformers-of-2024-hop-skip-jump/

Many great platformers were released this year, but one in particular stole the show. This list will compile some of the greatest platforming games released this year if you want a game that's fun for all the family or seek to introduce someone to gaming. Without further ado, here are Wccftech's five best platformers of 2024.

Previously on Wccftech's Best Games of 2024: Shooters, RPGs, Indies, Fighting, Horror, Action, DLC/Expansion, Adventure

Astro Bot (9.3/10)

It's no surprise that Astro Bot is on top. The game was well-received by critics and users across the globe, and many got to go on a journey of nostalgia and celebrate Sony's expansive lineage. Compared to Astro's Playroom, Astro Bot is a fully thought-out game where you get to jump, climb, glide, and fly across expansive levels while saving bots that are cameos from Sony's iconic games. Below is an excerpt from Kai Tatsumoto's review.

Everything that Astro Bot touches is filled with whimsy and amusement. The titular hero’s every animation is tinged with a sickeningly sweet charisma, from the way he carries himself throughout the stage on his own two feet or floating through the air via his high-tech jet back, going a few rounds to knock out rogue bots, and the idle animations that are unique to each level. All of the backdrop and tertiary characters of Astro Bot similarly share that wonder and charm and even the simple interactions between one mascot bot to another would never fail to put a smile on my face. 

Sonic x Shadow Generations

For fans of the Sonic franchise, Sonic x Shadow Generations was a dream come true. Although fans initially thought it was going just to be a simple remaster, it is evident that the game is much more than that and provides more content than players expected. Not only did the graphics receive a massive boost and give more detail than ever to both Sonic and Shadow, but it seems that a bit of Sonic Frontiers rubbed off on the game, too.

Sonic x Shadow Generations is a great title if you want to introduce your children to gaming or get them to love the Sonic franchise, too. There may be some difficult moments, but you can always step in and complete the boss fight for them if they're struggling a lot.

Mario vs. Donkey Kong (8/10)

It isn't all that shocking that a Nintendo game has made it into one of the top spots for best Platformer of 2024. If there's one thing that Nintendo does best, it's this genre. Mario vs Donkey Kong was released in February this year.

For those who played the original, this may serve as a sweet hit of nostalgia. For those new to the game, it's still a fun time all around. This game has plenty of value for money, too, as you can play through over 130 levels, experiencing the classic platformer in a new light. Here's what Nathan Birch said in Wccftech's review:

Mario vs. Donkey Kong may lack the razzle dazzle of its stars’ more recent games, but this remake still has the power to hook players with its tried-and-true retro platforming and a finely-tuned difficulty curve that culminates in some challenges that will truly test your mind and reflexes. Those who have played the original Mario vs. DK to death may not find quite enough new content here, but lapsed fans and new players are in for a barrel of fun.

Disney's Epic Mickey: Rebrushed (7.5/10)

Disney's Epic Mickey was a fantastic game that was first released in 2010 on the Nintendo Wii. Fast forward 14 years, and we have now experienced the remastered release of Disney's Epic Mickey: Rebrushed. It's a fantastic game and a great way to introduce youngsters to gaming. It takes you on a journey through Disney's forgotten history while you get to wield a paintbrush to help you traverse the terrain, as well as utilize your paintbrush to take on bosses in the world.

For what it is, the game is a pretty great remaster of a Disney classic title and will provide a lot of nostalgia for those who played and loved the original. Some systems were improved, while others fell behind a little bit. While it is a fantastic game, it's undoubtedly no Astro Bot and does have some flaws that may make the game a bit tiresome after a while.

The Plucky Squire (7/10)

The Plucky Squire is the perfect game if you want to introduce young children to gaming. While some of the mechanics may seem a little bit complicated at first, it's very easy to get the hang of and really accessible. When it comes to platformers that were released this year, The Plucky Squire is incredibly unique in the way it tackles traversal and movement through the game.

It's more than just a platformer, though, as there's also fun combat to engage in, a storyline to experience, and lots of collectibles to discover as you solve puzzles. The game is a lot of fun and great for anyone of any age.

item.title: Jason Momoa Confirms His Return To The DCU Will Be In Next Supergirl Film
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/jason-momoa-lobo-supergirl-superman-news-1851730213

Cinematic continuity be damned, Jason Momoa is putting the fish gills down for tattoos and violence. According to reports from Deadline, the man known around the world as Aquaman formally announced his return to the DC universe as the invulnerable Lobo in Supergirl: Woman of Tomorrow.

Suggested Reading

Live Forever in the Universe of 'New World: Aeternum'

Suggested Reading

For those unaware of the terrifying force that is Lobo, just know he’s an intergalactic bounty hunter who causes genocides for fun and once bragged about killing Santa Claus. Lobo has had his fair share of brutal encounters with Supergirl’s cousin Superman in the comics, so the two of them were bound to collide sooner or later. In an Instagram post, Momoa shared a quote from his 2023 Fandango interview in which he revealed that the long-haired, muscular menace was his favorite comic book character growing up, calling it “the perfect role.” He confirmed his involvement in the movie with a simple two-word caption: “They called.”

Details of the Supergirl: Woman of Tomorrow film are still under wraps outside of its June 26, 2026 release date and House of the Dragon’s Milly Alcock being cast as the lead. That would make it the second movie in James Gunn’s new DC Universe, with Gunn’s highly anticipated Superman as the first. That one’s slated to arrive on July 11, 2025.

It would be pretty funny if Gunn’s new DC cinematic universe also ends up including a Justice League. If so, would Momoa pull double duty and don the fish scales again? Or are we done with the Avengers-style superhero mashups? Only Gunn knows the answer. Luckily, one thing we do know now is that arguably the single most important actor to the DC films over the last decade will be returning as a villain, just like Robert Downey Jr. will debut as Doctor Doom in Avengers: Doomsday, which is slated to come out a month before Supergirl.

Sometimes you stay relevant long enough to see yourself become the villain because studios desperately need you.

item.title: SNK Creates New Studio For Its Fighting Games
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/snk-creates-new-studio-for-its-fighting-games/

SNK has announced the creation of a knew studio for its fighting games called KOF Studio. KOF Studios’ role will be to help “further evolve the SNK fighting game IP”.

The move comes alongside the 30th anniversary of the studio’s The King of Fighters franchise.

“Since their creation in the 1990s, fighting game series such as “Garou Densetsu”, “Samurai Shodown”, and “The King of Fighters” have been loved by fans around the world,” SNK said in its announcement via translation.

Currently, SNK has a number of games in development within the aforementioned franchises. Fatal Fury: City of the Wolves is scheduled for release in April 2025, and will be the first release for the series since Fatal Fury: First Contact in 1999. There’s also a new action RPG Samurai Shodown game in early development.

The King of Fighters’ last game launched in 2022. There’s been no mention on when the next game in the series could be coming.

item.title: Neva's Voice Acting Is Incredible, And It Only Ever Says One Word
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/nevas-voice-acting-is-incredible-and-it-only-ever-says-one-word/1100-6528483/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

From the first trailer, I knew Neva would be an emotional experience. Nomada Studio's previous game, Gris, was a poignant exploration of grief and the effects it can have on a person, told through the lens of a young girl who'd just lost her mother. Neva explores familial bonds through a different but just as emotional lens: parenthood.

The relationship between Alba and Neva mirrors a mother/child relationship through most of the game. The wolf starts as a small cub, curious about the world and ready to explore, and eventually he becomes a strong protector, equaling his mother's capabilities. From there, the two fight against the blight that's affecting the world, with Neva learning new abilities in every season.

The journey encompassing this coming of age includes some of the strongest voice acting you'll find in a video game this year. However, unlike games like Final Fantasy VII Rebirth and Metaphor: ReFantazio, which are bursting with dialogue, Neva accomplishes this feat with a much smaller script; throughout the entire five-hour adventure, only one word is ever spoken.

Neva's control scheme is standard fare for an action-platformer: one button to attack, one button to jump, one button to dodge, etc. Included in the control scheme, though, is a button specifically designated for calling Neva. No matter what you're doing, or where you are, a simple press will make Alba say "Neva" and call out for the good wolfie girl.

While the mechanic has its uses--you can call Neva to your side if she's far away, or instruct her to jump up a ledge--it's mostly just there for the player's enjoyment. Calling Neva usually results in Alba giving her companion a little scratch behind the ears--which means yes, in Neva, you can pet the dog.

Its biggest contribution to the story, and what sends Neva into the upper echelon of 2024 voice acting, is the emotion Alba conveys whenever the button is pressed. When there's little danger around, and Neva is sniffing around or standing still, Alba's voice is calm, loving, and light. The character's love for her companion comes through, especially when it's followed by sounds of delight from both characters following a loving head scratch.

Press that button in a more urgent moment, however, and Alba's voice becomes much heavier. There's urgency in her calls, permeated by a sense of panic. Her anxiety and fear come to the surface, and all it takes is a change in inflection. It's powerful stuff, and it makes using the call button more than worth it even in hectic situations.

There's one moment in particular that really highlights how effective this voice acting can be. Alba and Neva are separated, and the player as Alba must traverse a perilous maze in order to reunite with the wolf. Throughout this endeavor, pressing the call button makes Alba utter a cry of pure terror, helplessly shouting into the void in search of her lost companion. The fear of the unknown is palpable, and I start to feel Alba's anxiety with her as I hear her call the wolf's name.

Now, putting Alba's ability to call out for Neva on a button is not without its pitfalls. By doing this, Nomada ran the risk of some players not being able to hear the exceptional voice work at hand, simply because they were so focused on the action on screen that they were too busy attacking and dodging to press the call button.

However, Nomada brilliantly trained us to keep it in the back of our minds through the mechanic I mentioned earlier: the one where Alba uses her call to summon Neva to her side. The player now knows that calling Neva can summon her, so once the two are separated, it's natural to press the button and see if it works--and when it doesn't, to keep trying it in the hopes that maybe it will work eventually.

Anyone who's ever been in care of a child and lost sight of them--be it in a store, a theme park, or even in their own homes--can relate to this feeling of paralyzing fear, uncertainty, and doubt… as well as the feeling of sheer relief when Alba finds Neva happily sitting on a platform, not a care in the world, as if nothing happened. Kids these days!

Neva is a profound analysis of parenthood, and all of the highs and lows that come with it. The raw emotion is best conveyed through its voice acting, credited to Cristina Peña, and putting Alba's voice under the player's control makes it that much more effective. Nomada Studio deserves a ton of credit for finding a way to convey the intricate complexities of being a caregiver--and even more credit for doing it with a single word.

item.title: Stardew Valley sales grew to over 41 million by 2024's end
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamedeveloper.com/business/stardew-valley-sales-grew-to-over-41-million-by-2024-s-end

Developer Eric "ConcernedApe" Barone's country life-RPG Stardew Valley has sold over 41 million copies, according to its website. That milestone covers its release on PC, Mac, Nintendo Switch, PlayStation 4, Xbox One, and mobile.

The website's press page specifically highlights its PC and Switch sales: over 26 million units are from the former, and 7.9 million units from the latter. It's unclear how well Stardew has sold on other systems.

In February, Barone revealed his game had sold over 30 million copies, and said it was "thriving more than ever." At the time, Stardew Valley had turned eight years old and was about to receive its 1.6 update weeks later in March. When the update launched, the game hit an all-time peak of 236,614 concurrent players, according to SteamDB.

Since its 2016 launch, Stardew's sales have continuously grown alongside its expansion to other platforms. While it's currently unavailable for PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X|S, it can be played on those systems via backwards compatibility.

Alongside Stardew Valley, Barone is also developing Haunted Chocolatier, another simulation game based around running a candy store.

item.title: Champion Magnus Carlsen Rocked The Chess World By Refusing To Take Off His Jeans
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/magnus-carlsen-jeans-chess-blitz-championship-fide-1851730179

The chess world is never short on scandals, and the latest one is incredibly on brand. Top-ranked former world champion Magnus Carlsen recently showed up to a tournament in jeans, refused to change, got fined, and then threatened to back out of the event altogether. The International Chess Federation (FIDE) then proceeded to blink first.

Suggested Reading

Live Forever in the Universe of 'New World: Aeternum'

Suggested Reading

The drama kicked off on December 27 when Carlsen showed up to the World Rapid and Blitz Chess Championships in New York wearing denim instead of slacks. FIDE said the chess world all-star was in violation of the event’s dress code and hit him with a $200 fine. When Carlsen refused to go pick up dress pants from the TJ Maxx just a block away from the Cipriani Wall Street venue, the federation upped the ante and removed the champion from his 9th round matchups.

Carlsen then called the federation’s bluff by saying he would back out altogether, ditching the Blitz Chess Championships in which he was set to defend his current title. The federation responded with a lengthy blog post announcing possible exceptions to the dress code to be made at the judges’ discretion.

“The principle is simple: it is still required to follow the official dress-code, but elegant minor deviations (that may, in particular, include appropriate jeans matching the jacket) are allowed,” the December 29 announcement read. “In the end, it is New Year time, and I sincerely hope that nobody would try to undermine the festive mood, including by abusing this additional flexibility.”

In an interview directly after the incident, Carlsen said that he had come to the event from a meeting and hadn’t had time to change. He added that while he had offered to change for the matches the following day, that wasn’t enough for the federation. “I’ll probably head off to somewhere where the weather is a bit nicer than here,” he quipped. But now that FIDE has backed off of its “draconian” decision, Carlsen is once again set to appear in the Blitz side of the tournament.

The five-time world champion wasn’t the only one dinged over his attire. Eighth-ranked Ian Nepomniachtchi was also fined by FIDE for wearing “sport shoes.” But Carlsen’s protest certainly made for more drama. Hans Neimann, who Carlsen previously accused of cheating in chess’ now-infamous “anal beads” scandal, said the champion had manufactured the jeans fiasco on purpose.

“Allowing a single actor to make a mockery of the tournament and then bending the knee is disappointing,” he tweeted. “FIDE has a responsibility to protect the sanctity of the game. The chesscom mafia tried to ruin my career because of a similar emotional outburst, someone must take a stand!”

Carlsen, meanwhile, plans to keep flouting the dress code, at least for the time being. “Oh, I am definitely playing in jeans tomorrow,” he tweeted over the weekend.

item.title: Stardew Valley Hits Another Sales Milestone

Stardew Valley has hit another sales milestone. According to the game’s developer ConcernedApe, the game has sold over 41 million copies as of December 2024.

That total puts it roughly 11 million more than the “over 30 million” it surpassed earlier 2024. According to the game’s website, 26 million of the 41 million copies have been sold on PC while another 7.9 million were sold on Nintendo Switch.

Released in 2016, Stardew Valley was a solo-developed game that has continued to see major updates nearly nine years later. The last major update — 1.6 — saw new festivals and events added along with hundreds of other changes.

In addition to game updates, the game continues to hit new player count records. Even the music has found its place in the hearts of players with a full orchestra tour performing the game’s soundtrack. Lastly, a recent study found that Stardew Valley was the best game for reducing stress.

item.title: SNK starts up new studio to 'evolve' its fighting game franchises
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamedeveloper.com/business/snk-starts-up-new-studio-to-evolve-its-fighting-game-franchises

Japanese developer SNK recently established a new studio focused on its various fighting game franchises. Dubbed KOF Studio, it aims to "further evolve the SNK fighting game IP," according to a translation of its announcement.

Fighting game properties under SNK include Fatal Fury, Samurai Shodown, and King of Fighters. The latter series had a new installment in 2022, and the most recent Samurai Shodown (or Samurai Spirits in Japan) came in 2019. The next Fatal Fury game is April 2025's Fatal Fury: City of the Wolves, which marks its first new title in over 25 years.

An action-RPG Samurai Shodown is in development, and SNK is currently hiring for that project.

This past June, SNK formally announced a Singaporean studio to help "develop high-quality games through enhanced cooperation" with its Japanese teams. Developers based in that region are rare, and the effort is part of SNK's aim of becoming a "top 10 global publisher" within the next decade.

SNK has always had a strong presence in the fighting game genre. But its commitment to revitalizing its franchises within that space is not too dissimilar from what Capcom has been doing with its own game library in recent years, such as Dragon's Dogma and Mega Man.

Earlier in December, the Resident Evil developer unveiled new games for its Okami and Onimusha franchises. Both have not had new entries in a decade or longer, but Capcom explained it wanted to try its hand at reviving series it had left dormant.

Similarly, PlayStation co-CEO Herman Hulst recently indicated the console maker would be open to "leveraging" its property, potentially with third-party studios.

item.title: Space Marine 2 Is Getting More PvP Content, Horde Mode, and More Next Year
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/space-marine-2-2025-outline-pvp

Space Marine 2 publisher Focus Entertainment has shared what's coming to the Warhammer 40k shooter in 2025, and if you're a fan of the PvP game modes, you'll be pleased with the roadmap.

In a new December community update, Focus first looks at the last few months for Space Marine 2, highlighting things like major updates and the game's rather impressive sales figures.

Following the 2024 recap, Focus then moves onto highlighting what you can expect from next year in Space Marine 2, and the first thing on the agenda is more PvP content. The publisher says it knows PvP fans feel "left out", and so next year will bring a new map, custom lobbies, and more.

New PvE stuff is also coming next year, starting with the Horde mode, which was teased back when Space Marine 2's first post-launch roadmap was revealed in late August. New Operations and enemies are also on the way for you to tackle.

We also got a look at the next champion making his way to Space Marine 2, and it's a Salamander sniper. Focus acknowledges that the Raven Guard Chapter would have been "an obvious choice" for a sniper, but that the studio has "different plans" for the Raven Guard.

More customization options are also coming, alongside a new Datavault option on the Battle Barge. It'll allow you to read "unlockable information on most elements from the game", in case you want to brush up on your Space Marine 2 lore.

In case you're not familiar with Space Marine 2, it's a third-person shooter set in the grim darkness of the Warhammer 40k universe.

The game sees protagonist Demetrian Titus returning from the first game. Having spent time with the Deathwatch in order to prove himself free of heresy, Titus is re-inducted into the Ultramarines and tasked with eradicating a Tyrannid infestation on the planet Kadaku.

Like its predecessor, Space Marine 2 emphasizes both close-quarters combat and ranged weaponry, and it's also got a renewed focus on co-op play. Fittingly enough, its credits also feature a rather touching tribute to a man who championed the original title.

You can pick up Space Marine 2 right now on PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S. If you want to know my thoughts on this Space Marine simulator, you can check out my review here.

item.title: A Major Marvel Rivals Bug Has Some Fans Calling The Game ‘Pay To Win’
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/marvel-rivals-framerate-bug-glitch-pay-to-win-wolverine-1851730140

The term “pay to win” is typically attributed to competitive games with microtransactions that give players an edge in battle. An example would be an item you can buy that makes your character more powerful than that of someone who didn’t cough up real money. However, some Marvel Rivals fans are throwing the derogatory label onto the hero shooter because of a bug that’s giving some users an unexpected advantage in fights. While you could argue that this situation has folks throwing around the phrase “pay to win” a little too liberally, the bug in question is certainly one that should be addressed by developer NetEase.

Fans have realized that when Marvel Rivals is running at lower framerates, some hero abilities do less damage or are generally less efficient than they are at higher framerates. In other words, if you’re playing the shooter on a high-end PC that can run the game at a higher framerate, you’ll find your enemies will take more damage from certain attacks than they would if you were playing on a machine that runs the game at a lower framerate. Other idiosyncrasies include certain attacks executing more quickly, or seemingly losing range at lower framerates. The reason some fans are calling this “pay to win” is because if you can afford a beefier PC, you can circumvent the issue entirely.

Currently, this bug is known to impact five characters: Star-Lord, Wolverine, Doctor Strange, Magik, and Spider-Man. At the moment, this is a bigger problem for players on PC than on console, as those all play at the same framerate across the board. However, Marvel Rivals is crossplay, which means you could be teamed up with a PC player affected by this, so it’s a problem for everyone until it’s fixed.

Marvel Rivals has received a few patches that have primarily focused on bug fixes, so that seems to be top of mind for the team. Now that this issue has been discovered, hopefully NetEase will be looking into a fix. For more on Marvel Rivals, check out Kotaku’s review.
